content:
The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 is the short title of the Act. It aims to improve coordination of export promotion programs. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to consolidate duplicative export promotion activities, clarify roles of Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee members, include State agency representatives on the committee, and report on improvements to Export.gov and developing a single window for export information. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 aims to streamline export promotion activities, clarify roles of Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee members, include State agency representatives, and report on improvements to Export.gov and developing a single window for export information. The Small Business Export Growth Act of 2012 includes provisions for promoting exporting, small business export matchmaking, export control education, inter-agency task force on export financing, and availability of State resource guides on Export.gov. It also aims to consolidate duplicative export promotion activities and provide information about trade missions and trade fairs. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include identifying opportunities for consolidating or co-locating offices of agencies involved in export financing activities and enhancing the use of electronic databases for resource allocation. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include enhancing the use of electronic databases for resource allocation and providing a detailed listing of trade missions and related activities for better service delivery to US businesses. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include providing a detailed listing of current and future Federal and State-led trade missions, trade fairs, and related activities for better service delivery to US businesses. The Secretary of Commerce will make this information available on Export.gov or a successor website. SEC. 102. CLARIFICATION OF ROLES OF MEMBERS OF TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to clarify the roles of each department or agency that is a member of the TPCC in export promotion and financing activities. This includes identifying and explaining the department or agency's role, describing goals and objectives, and providing rationale for their activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 amends Section 2312(c) to clarify the roles of TPCC members in export promotion. This involves identifying roles, describing goals, and providing rationale for activities. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 clarifies the roles of TPCC members in export promotion, including setting goals and objectives, reporting on them, and incorporating recommendations from the Comptroller General of the United States. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 clarifies the roles of TPCC members in export promotion, including setting goals, reporting, and incorporating recommendations from the Comptroller General of the United States. Amendments include adding recommendations related to coordination and updating the organization's name to the United States Travel Association. SEC. 103 amends the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include a representative of state agencies on the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee. SEC. 104 requires reports to Congress on the activities of the Committee. Section 2312(f) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to require the chairperson of the TPCC to submit an annual report to Congress by March 30. The report must detail the strategic plan developed by the TPCC, its implementation, any revisions, and the implementation of specific sections of the FREEDOM Support Act. The TPCC chairperson must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, funding for export promotion activities, and interagency working groups on energy. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce is required to prepare and submit reports on these matters. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce prepares and submits reports to Congress annually on the TPCC's performance in carrying out its duties related to export promotion activities and interagency working groups on energy. The Department of Commerce submits an annual report to Congress on the TPCC's performance in carrying out its duties and implementing the strategic plan. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults in preparing the report. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other Federal departments in preparing the annual report on the TPCC's performance. The term 'appropriate congressional committees' is defined in this subsection. The Inspector General of the Department of Commerce consults with other Federal departments in preparing the annual report on the TPCC's performance. The term 'appropriate congressional committees' includes specific Senate and House committees. The appropriate congressional committees for the annual report on the TPCC's performance include specific Senate and House committees related to appropriations, commerce, finance, foreign relations, small business, entrepreneurship, energy, financial services, foreign affairs, and ways and means. SEC. 105. REPORT ON IMPROVEMENTS TO EXPORT.GOV AS A SINGLE WINDOW FOR EXPORT INFORMATION. The Director of International Trade of the Small Business Administration will submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act, with recommendations for enhancing Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for U.S. exporters. The Director of International Trade will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for improving Export.gov as a comprehensive resource for U.S. exporters, including small business concerns. Entities specified for providing information required by the Federal Government on exportation from the United States include small business exporters and various trade-related organizations. SEC. 106. REPORT ON DEVELOPING A SINGLE WINDOW FOR INFORMATION ABOUT EXPORT CONTROL COMPLIANCE. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and regulations, and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration must submit a report to congressional committees within 180 days of this Act's enactment, evaluating the benefits of creating a website as a comprehensive resource for export control laws and regulations, and a single platform for exporters to submit required information to the Federal Government. The appropriate congressional committees are defined as specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. TITLE II--FACILITATION OF EXPORT OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES

SEC. 201. DEFINITIONS.
- Defines "Administration" and "Administrator" as the Small Business Administration and its head respectively.
- Defines "region of the Administration" as per section 3(u) of the Small Business Act.
- Defines "small business concern" as per section 3 of the Small Business Act.

SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. SEC. 202. PROMOTION OF EXPORTING. Amends the Small Business Act to include conducting outreach events in each State promoting exporting as a business opportunity for small businesses. SEC. 203. SMALL BUSINESS EXPORT MATCHMAKING PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events in each region to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers or international clients. At least one event will be held annually in each region, and events may be coordinated with outreach events required under the Small Business Act. The Administrator will establish a pilot program for matchmaking events in each region to connect small businesses with potential foreign buyers or international clients. The program may hold a matchmaking event in coordination with an outreach event required under the Small Business Act. The authority of the Administrator under this section shall terminate on September 30, 2015. SEC. 204 amends the Small Business Act to prioritize educating small businesses on Federal export control regulations. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing. SEC. 205 establishes a Small Business Inter-Agency Task Force on Export Financing to review and improve Federal export finance programs for small businesses and coordinate government activities to assist small businesses in exporting. The Secretary of Commerce will provide State resource guides on Export.gov, detailing export promotion and financing resources in each State, including State agencies, district export councils, and trade associations.
